posts.name: acastagna
posts.cooked:
We are working on targeting and aligning with a limelight and see that the targeting data gets updated about once every 3 cycles of the scheduler, or about 60ms.  I saw that the rate can be increased by calling the flush method peridoically. We tried that but there was no change.

We creatie an instance of the network table in the constructor of a command with:

We call  ntInstance.flush()  in the execute() method.  We can print out table entries (tx, ta) with a time stamp, and we see values with time stamps at about 20ms intervals as expected, but ta and tx change only about every 60ms.

Should the flush call be made somewhere else? Or done in some other way?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
I’m assuming the above code is running on the Rio, and receiving info from the Limelight?

Flush() only affects outgoing data (data you set).  It cannot make another node (in this case the Limelight) send you data more frequently.

posts.name: acastagna
posts.cooked: Ahh  - ok. Is there a way to retrieve data more frequently from the limelight ?  Run a custom python code on the limelight and have it flush from there ?
I’m not 100% sure, but I’m believe that the Limelight updates the data as soon as it finishes processing a new frame. What FPS is your Limelight running at?

posts.name: acastagna
posts.cooked: I’ll tale a look tomorrow. I don’t think we did anything to change it from whatever the default is.

60ms is around 16 FPS, which the Limelight can definitely fall to if you are running a really high resolution on it and also depending on the exact model of Limelight you have. Also, are you running April Tags or retro-reflective tracking? Both have methods of tuning to increase the frame rate to maximize tracking performance and FPS.

You can check out the docs here .

posts.name: acastagna
posts.cooked: I see it now - thank you. We are now working on a nice compromise between frame rate, range and accuracy using the camera settings.
